meanings.def: used when the two numbers or amounts mentioned are being added together
examples: Two plus five is seven.
The cost is £22, plus £1 for postage.
Membership is 350 dollars per year plus tax.

meanings.def: as well as something/somebody; and also
examples: We have to fit five of us plus all our gear in the car.

meanings.def: used when the number mentioned may actually be more or less by a particular amount
examples: The margin of error was plus or minus three percentage points.

idioms.def: used when the number mentioned may actually be more or less by a particular amount
examples: The margin of error was plus or minus three percentage points.

meanings.def: used after a number to show that the real number or amount is more than the one mentioned
examples: The work will cost £10 000 plus.
Sales are growing by 20 per cent plus per year.
The temperature is plus four degrees.

meanings.def: used to describe an aspect of something that you consider to be a good thing
examples: One of the hotel's plus points is that it is very central.
On the plus side, all the staff are enthusiastic.
The plus side of working at home is that you can be more flexible.

meanings.def: slightly higher than the grade A, B, etc.
examples: I got B plus (B+) in the test.
Knowledge of French is a plus in her job.
There were a lot of pluses in the performance.
plus for somebody/something Ease of use is a big plus for any game.
One of the pluses of the job is having such supportive colleagues.
You should carefully consider the pluses and minuses of going to live in the country.
He put a plus instead of a minus.
I've got too much on at work. Plus my father is not well.

meanings.def: used as a way of saying that people and situations never really change over time, although they may appear to

idioms.def: used as a way of saying that people and situations never really change over time, although they may appear to
